key_points: The jury began deliberation on whether Kyle Rittenhouse, an 18-year-old from Illinois, would be found guilty of multiple charges related to a confrontation in Kenosha, Wisconsin on August 25, 2020.
Rittenhouse, 17 at the time, was armed with an AR-15 style semi-automatic weapon and shot three people, killing two and injuring one, during civil unrest following the police shooting of Jacob Blake.
Rittenhouse maintains he acted in self-defence.

He faces charges including First-Degree Reckless Homicide, two counts of First-Degree Recklessly Endangering Safety, First-Degree Intentional Homicide, Attempted First-Degree Intentional Homicide, and Failure to Comply.
Judge Bruce Schroeder dismissed the Possession of a Dangerous Weapon By A Person Under 18 charge due to a legal loophole.
Schroeder also dismissed the Failure to Comply charge, citing insufficient evidence from the prosecution.
Rittenhouse was allowed by Judge Schroeder to draw juror numbers who would decide his fate.
The jury began deliberations at 8:15 A.M. on November 16 and paused for the night to resume the following morning.
Public opinion is reflected through more than 545 comments on K2 Radio News' Facebook page, with the majority seeming to support Rittenhouse's acquittal.
Some public comments sparked heated debates, indicating strong feelings on the case.
